Writing Prompt: "Describe your experience standing in line at the post office."

Text:
"The line stretches out before me, an endless snake of people. I've been here for what feels like hours already. The woman in front of me has her packages all neat and tidy, labeled perfectly with those fancy printed labels. Mine are a mess, haphazardly wrapped in brown paper, the addresses scrawled in my hurried, messy handwriting. I can't help but feel self-conscious, comparing my disorganized parcels to hers.

The man behind me has his phone out, checking the time every five minutes. Each glance he casts at his watch feels like a judgment, a silent comparison of our respective paces. I'm sure he's thinking, 'Why is this guy so slow? He's holding up the line.'

I shuffle my feet, trying to distract myself from these thoughts. But it's no use. The line inches forward, and with each step, I feel more aware of my shortcomings. The man ahead of me has a stack of neatly filled-out forms; mine are crumpled in my pocket, forgotten until the last moment.

As I reach the counter, I'm flustered, apologetic, feeling like everyone's watching, waiting for me to fail."

A seasoned surgeon, known for his meticulousness, finds out that one of his patients has made an unexpected recovery after a complicated procedure. He immediately dismisses it as luck rather than acknowledging his own skill.

**Text:**

"Another damned lucky break," he muttered under his breath, flipping through the patient's chart with unnecessary force. The nurse on the other side of the counter raised an eyebrow but said nothing. He barely noticed her; his mind was too busy picking apart the recovery report.

"It's unheard of, really," he continued, more to himself than anyone else. "A complication like that, and she just... recovers? Without so much as a hitch?" His voice dripped with skepticism, echoing through the bustling ward.

He slammed the chart shut, his frustration evident in every line of his body. "I've seen this before," he declared, more to himself than anyone else. "People thinking we're some kind of miracle workers. It's not skill, it's not expertise - it's just chance." He strode off down the hall, leaving a trail of disgruntled silence behind him.
